instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.LCD_BKLT_EN: What is LCD_BKLT_EN? This is an enable signal. Anytime you see “_EN”, it means when the voltage is high(3.3 volts), whatever it is going to is being turned on or enabled. Here, “LCD_BKLT” which stands for “LCD screen backlight” is being enabled. This signal usually goes to an LED driver used for creating a power rail for the LCD screen backlight, to tell it to turn on & create this rail. .
definitions.LVDS_IG_BKL_ON: What is LVDS_IG_BKL_ON? LVDS_IG_BKL_ON is equivalent to LCD_BKLT_EN. This signal usually goes to an LED driver used for creating a power rail for the LCD screen backlight, to tell it to turn on & create this rail. .
definitions.LCDBKLT_EN_L: What is LCDBKLT_EN_L? This signal enables the backlight when it is low.  _L means the signal asserts itself when the voltage is low. This signal needs to be low to enable backlight. .
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.Q9706: What is Q9706? Q9706 takes PPBUS_G3H's vltage and sends it through to the backlight circuit. If Q9706 is not allowing PPBUS_G3H through, you will get no voltage on the backlight circuit. Q9706 is a P channel MOSFET, meaning power will flow through it when the voltage on the gate is lower than on the source. Look at pin 3. R9788 takes the 12.6v that is on the source and places it right on pin 3. This will set Q9706 to "off", and not allow it to pass power, as the voltage on the source and the gate are identical..
definitions.LCD_PWR_EN: What is LCD_PWR_EN? LCD_PWR_EN is a signal that tells the chip that supplies power to the LCD screen to turn on..
definitions.LVDS_DDC_CLK: What is LVDS_DDC_CLK? LVDS_DDC_CLK Is the DDC clock line between the graphics processor and the screen. DDC is a protocol for identifying a screen so that you know what resolution/refresh rate it wants. This is necessary for screen detection, inductor on this data line must be good and DDC voltage must be going to the LCD screen for it to work. .
definitions.LVDS_DDC_DATA: What is LVDS_DDC_DATA? LVDS_DDC_DATA Is the DDC data line between the graphics processor and the screen. DDC is a protocol for identifying a screen so that you know what resolution/refresh rate it wants. This is necessary for screen detection, inductor on this data line must be good and DDC voltage must be going to the LCD screen for it to work. .
definitions.D9701: What is D9701? diode in the backlight circuit sitting between the BKL_SW pin of the LED driver and backlight output. Very common for via between this and BKL_FB for feedback to blow, causing no boost. Measure continuity between pin 2 of this diode and feedback pin of LED driver if backlight output is PPBUS_G3H with no boost.
definitions.LP8550: What is LP8550? This is an LED driver responsible for creating the backlight on the LCD screen of Macbooks from 2011 through 2015.
definitions.820-3209: What is 820-3209? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight - missing <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
[COLOR=#333333][FONT=Verdana][SIZE=13px]This board had a blown F9700 fuse and 0v on <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>. I replaced F9700 but I am still getting 0v on <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>. <SIGNAL>BKLT_PLT_RST_L</SIGNAL> measures 3.3v.[/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]

[COLOR=#333333][FONT=Verdana][SIZE=13px]I googled around and saw that <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> comes from <SIGNAL>LVDS_IG_BKL_ON</SIGNAL> so I measured <RESISTOR>R1981</RESISTOR> and that measured a proper 100k.[/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]

[COLOR=#333333][FONT=Verdana][SIZE=13px]There was some water damage around the <CHIP>U1800</CHIP> and <TRANSISTOR>Q9707</TRANSISTOR> area. I have given the area a 99% alcohol and toothbrush scrub since I dont have an ultrasonic yet.[/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#333333][FONT=Verdana][SIZE=13px]I have done the testing with the display connected. The LVDS connector and cable both look fine. When I disconnect the display and use my thunderbolt to hdmi cable on my tv it works fine.[/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#333333][FONT=Verdana][SIZE=13px]Would this probably be a problem with the <CHIP>U1800</CHIP> chip since that is where <SIGNAL>LVDS_IG_BKL_ON</SIGNAL> is produced?[/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight - missing <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Diode mode reading on <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> (red probe to ground black probe to <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT</SIGNAL> EN)....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight - missing <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
[QUOTE="aprendiz, post: 1364"]Diode mode reading on <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> (red probe to ground black probe to <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT</SIGNAL> EN)....[/QUOTE]
I measured Pin 5(<SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>) of <TRANSISTOR>Q9707</TRANSISTOR> in diode mode and got 0.557. Is that the proper voltage?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight - missing <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message: it is ok, water damage on LVDS connector?? maybe a bad connector or cable, screen is not been detected...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight - missing <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
[QUOTE="aprendiz, post: 1375"]it is ok, water damage on LVDS connector?? maybe a bad connector or cable, screen is not been detected...[/QUOTE]
The connector and cable look fine. There was some blue corrosion on <CAPACITOR>C9797</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C9799</CAPACITOR> so I replaced those two earlier.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight - missing <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I checked <TRANSISTOR>Q9707</TRANSISTOR> again and I see that Pin 3(<SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_EN_L</SIGNAL>) is showing 12v in voltage mode and 0.99v in diode mode.
There is still 0v on <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>.
I don't see how <SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_EN_L</SIGNAL> is getting any voltage. Shouldn't the mosfet only open when there is a higher voltage on the gate then the source?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight - missing <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<TRANSISTOR>Q9706</TRANSISTOR> is a P type MOSFET that will only open when the voltage on the gate is much lower than the voltage on the source. <RESISTOR>R9788</RESISTOR> & <RESISTOR>R9789</RESISTOR> are a voltage divider whose purpose it is to send 5v to the gate of <TRANSISTOR>Q9706</TRANSISTOR>. A voltage divider needs a path to a lower voltage/ground on the "bottom" for it to work though, which means <RESISTOR>R9789</RESISTOR> needs a path to ground.

<RESISTOR>R9789</RESISTOR> doesn't get a path to ground unless <TRANSISTOR>Q9707</TRANSISTOR> opens. <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>BKLT_PLT_RST_L</SIGNAL> need to be present in order for <TRANSISTOR>Q9707</TRANSISTOR> to open, allow <RESISTOR>R9788</RESISTOR>/<RESISTOR>R9789</RESISTOR> voltage divider to work, and allow <TRANSISTOR>Q9706</TRANSISTOR> to pass power.

This usually happens when the LCD is recognized. If <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> isn't present, either <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> is stuck at a low voltage because of corrosion by BIL connector or the machine doesn't recognize the LCD.

What voltage is present on pin 2/3, and 4 of the LCD connector?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight - missing <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Thanks for the explanation.
Pins 2 and 3 of the LCD Connector show 0v and pin 4 shows 3.32v
Also I checked pin 5(<SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL>) of J6955 and <RESISTOR>R6961</RESISTOR> and got 3.45v. That number isn't low for <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> is it?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight - missing <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message: ok, so we end troubleshooting of no backlight, and start troubleshooting of screen detection. If <SIGNAL>LCD_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> is 0v on <CHIP>U9000</CHIP>(check that for me), the machine is not seeing the LCD. Do you have a known good LCD & cable lying around for testing? Have you reset PRAM? Do the resistors for <SIGNAL>LVDS_DDC_DATA</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>LVDS_DDC_CLK</SIGNAL> check out good?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight - missing <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I measured Pin 1(<SIGNAL>LCD_IG_PWR_EN</SIGNAL>) of <CHIP>U9000</CHIP> and got 0v. I checked the resistors you said to check and this is what I got.
<RESISTOR>R9008</RESISTOR> -  3.08kohms
<RESISTOR>R9009</RESISTOR> - 3.09kohms

I did a PRAM reset but nothing happened. 

The only other MBP I have is this one [url]http://www.everymac.com/systems/apple/macbook_pro/specs/macbook-pro-core-2-duo-2.26-aluminum-13-mid-2009-sd-firewire-800-unibody-specs.html[/url].
Would this be compatible with a 2012 MBP?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight - missing <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Measure on diode mode pin 6 and 7 on LCD connector and carefully inspect pin 4 for corrosion and 3V present.
The 2012 models have a unique LCD connector so no other models are compatible.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight - missing <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 1449"]Measure on diode mode pin 6 and 7 on LCD connector and carefully inspect pin 4 for corrosion and 3V present.
The 2012 models have a unique LCD connector so no other models are compatible.[/QUOTE]

In diode mode 
pin 6 - 0.514
pin 7 - 0.543

There doesn't look to be any corrosion on pin 4 and there is 3.32v on it.
Pins 6 and 7 also have 3.32v on them.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight - missing <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Is there anything else I can do besides replacing the screen?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight - missing <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message: pin 6 and 7 should read the same. Did you measure this with LCD plugged in?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight - missing <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Yes. that is with the cable plugged in. When I remove the cable pin 6 measures 0.605v and pin 7 measures 0.609v in diode mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight - missing <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message: At this point I would first try another LCD assembly to rule that out. Don't rip the original apart it might be fine. Get another machine to test or order a cable+LCD to test.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight - missing <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I just ordered a used lcd and cable from powerbook medic. Is that a good company to purchase from? I think louis might have some experience with them.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight - missing <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message: You'll get your stuff, but in my opinion they are too expensive. But if you want it quick then sure. Make sure the cable you ordered is for 2012+ models!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight - missing <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message: thanks. i ordered a used lcd for $20 from them.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight - missing <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
My lcd and cable I ordered came in today and I tested it and the lcd is still not being recognized as there is nothing on Pin 1(<SIGNAL>LCD_IG_PWR_EN</SIGNAL>) of <CHIP>U9000</CHIP>. 
I checked <RESISTOR>R1984</RESISTOR> and I also got no voltage there and 91kohms on the resistance.
Here are some measurements on the lcd connector with the cable plugged in
           diode mode | voltage
Pin 2 - 0.575            0v
Pin 3 - 0.575            0v
Pin 4 - 0.331            3.31v
Pin 6 - 0.604            3.31v
Pin 7 - 0.599            3.31v

Is this an issue with <CHIP>U1800</CHIP> chip?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight - missing <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Check if pin 4 6 and 7 actually have continuity to the LCD side of the cable. Also check <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> again to be 100% sure

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight - missing <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Ok. So before checking for continuity I decided to flip the cable connecting to the lcd upside down and now I am getting 3.31v on Pins 2 & 3 and the lcd is working but there is no backlight(saw questionmark folder with flashlight) so I will troubleshoot this issue. Thanks for the help if I need anymore I'll reply on this thread.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight - missing <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I am getting 12.5v on L9701 as well as <DIODE>D9701</DIODE> and the output of <CAPACITOR>C9799</CAPACITOR> is a constant 12.5v and in diode mode <CAPACITOR>C9799</CAPACITOR> measures 0.579 on output. I replaced <CAPACITOR>C9797</CAPACITOR>/<CAPACITOR>C9799</CAPACITOR> weeks ago as they had some corrosion so I don't think that could be the issue.
<SIGNAL>BKLT_PLT_RST_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> both show 3.3v.
I checked the feedback line of the <CHIP>U9701</CHIP> LED Driver and it doesn't look burned but I do have a several <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP>'s that I can replace it with.
Is this likely a LED Driver issue?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight - missing <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Hey [USER="2"]dukefawks[/USER] do you think I should replace the LED Driver since I am only getting 12.5 on the ouput capacitors?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight - missing <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Sure why not?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight - missing <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
​[USER="2"]dukefawks[/USER] [USER="1"]larossmann[/USER]  Ok so a bunch of confusing stuff has happened since I reflowed the LED Driver. I reflowed it to see if it would work before having to replace it and after reflowing I was getting 12v on pin 3 of <TRANSISTOR>Q9706</TRANSISTOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q9707</TRANSISTOR> which is too high and no voltage on the output pins of <TRANSISTOR>Q9706</TRANSISTOR>. 

I replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q9707</TRANSISTOR> but that made no difference.

I replaced <RESISTOR>R9788</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R9789</RESISTOR> even though they measured correct resistance because I thought that was causing pin 3 of <TRANSISTOR>Q9707</TRANSISTOR> to be so high. I didnt have a donor board for this model so I took the resistors from a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that had the same resistance but 1/20w instead of 1/16w(don't know if that is a big issue.)

Now after replacing those resistors I no longer have <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> and once again the board isn't seeing the lcd as there is no voltage on Pins 2/3 of the lcd connector and Pin 1(<SIGNAL>LCD_IG_PWR_EN</SIGNAL>) of <CHIP>U9000</CHIP>.

The lcd cable and connector look fine so I don't know what could have happened.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight - missing <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I don't know either, replace LCD connector.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight - missing <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
[USER="2"]dukefawks[/USER] [USER="1"]larossmann[/USER] 
Its been a few weeks now and I have tested this board with 2 screens (one used and one new AU Optronics B133EW07) and 2 different lcd cables.
I also replaced the lcd connector and I gave this board an ultrasonic cleaning. 
Is there anything else I can check for? [h=1][/h]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight - missing <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message: did you replace <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight - missing <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
[QUOTE="JorgePayar, post: 2769"]did you replace <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP>?[/QUOTE]

No. Louis said earlier in this thread that I shouldn't be worried about backlight if the screen is not even being recognized since I get 0v on Pin 1 of <CHIP>U9000</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight - missing <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message: this honestly sounds like a clunker at this point. either bad PCH or some broken via inside the board. if you want to torture yourself, this is the board to do it on.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight - missing <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Okay. Ill cut my ties with this one and it's going back on ebay.
